conclusion: The problem involves calculating the maximum power consumed by a resistor \( R \) in a circuit with a circular coil placed in a uniform magnetic field.
The power consumed by the resistor is given by \( P = I^2 R \), where \( I \) is the current in the circuit.
The emf induced in the coil is calculated using Faraday's law: \( \mathcal{E} = -N \frac{\Delta \Phi}{\Delta t} \), where \( \Delta \Phi \) is the change in magnetic flux.
The magnetic field \( B \) varies linearly with time as shown in the graph, starting at 0.2 T at \( t = 0 \) and reaching 0.4 T at \( t = 4 \, \text{s} \).
The slope of the magnetic field graph is calculated as \( \frac{\Delta B}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.4 \, \text{T} - 0.2 \, \text{T}}{4 \, \text{s}} = 0.05 \, \text{T/s} \).
The change in magnetic flux is calculated as \( \Delta \Phi = 0.05 \, \text{T/s} \cdot 1 \, \text{m}^2 \cdot 4 \, \text{s} = 0.2 \, \text{Wb} \).
The induced emf is calculated as \( \mathcal{E} = -N \frac{\Delta \Phi}{\Delta t} = -200 \cdot 0.05 \, \text{T/s} \cdot 1 \, \text{m}^2 = -10 \, \text{V} \).
The total resistance in the circuit is the sum of the resistance of the coil and the external resistor: \( R_{\text{total}} = r + R \).
The total resistance in the circuit is calculated as \( R_{\text{total}} = 10 \, \Omega + 50 \, \Omega = 60 \, \Omega \).
The current in the circuit is calculated using Ohm's law: \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R_{\text{total}}} = \frac{10 \, \text{V}}{60 \, \Omega} = \frac{1}{6} \, \text{A} \).
The power consumed by the resistor is calculated using \( P = I^2 R \).

The power consumed by the resistor is calculated as \( P = \left( \frac{1}{6} \, \text{A} \right)^2 \cdot 50 \, \Omega = \frac{1}{36} \, \text{A}^2 \cdot 50 \, \Omega = \frac{50}{36} \, \text{W} = \frac{25}{18} \, \text{W} \approx 1.39 \, \text{W} \).
The maximum power consumed by the resistor is \( \boxed{\frac{25}{18} \, \text{W}}\)
